    <item>
      <title>As Big Candy Ditches GMOs, Sugar Beet Farmers Hit A Sour Patch</title>
      <description><![CDATA[As companies shun genetically modified ingredients, they're buying more sugar extracted from sugar cane rather than beets. Sugar beet farmers are thinking of going back to conventional beets.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:31:00 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2016/05/12/477793556/as-big-candy-ditches-gmos-sugar-beet-farmers-hit-sour-patch?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>
      <guid>http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2016/05/12/477793556/as-big-candy-ditches-gmos-sugar-beet-farmers-hit-sour-patch?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</guid>
      <itunes:author>Dan Charles</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[As companies shun genetically modified ingredients, they're buying more sugar extracted from sugar cane rather than beets. Sugar beet farmers are thinking of going back to conventional beets.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>
      <itunes:duration>230</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>
      <itunes:image href="https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2016/05/12/candybars_wide-8474c8c1baf0acf7eb705960e5cfc31b622fd182.jpg?s=1400"/>

    </item>
    <item>
      <title>In Polluted India, Negative Ion Necklaces Vow To Help You Breathe Easier</title>
      <description><![CDATA[In India, there is money to be made fighting air pollution. NPR examines one product geared towards the bad air: a negative ion necklace.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:11 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477836061/in-polluted-india-negative-ion-necklaces-vow-to-help-you-breathe-easier?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>
      <guid>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477836061/in-polluted-india-negative-ion-necklaces-vow-to-help-you-breathe-easier?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</guid>
      <itunes:author>Geoff Brumfiel</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[In India, there is money to be made fighting air pollution. NPR examines one product geared towards the bad air: a negative ion necklace.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>
      <itunes:duration>164</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>
      <enclosure url="http://public.npr.org/anon.npr-mp3/npr/atc/2016/05/20160512_atc_in_polluted_india_negative_ion_necklaces_vow_to_help_you_breathe_easier.mp3?sc=16&orgId=1&forsearch=0&topicId=1025&d=164&p=2&story=477836061&t=progseg&e=477760873&seg=18&ft=ryop&f=1007" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Indian Auto Maker Balances Luxury With Global Sustainability</title>
      <description><![CDATA[The luxury brand Jaguar is now owned by an Indian car company, Tata. A drive through the Los Angeles hills in a super high-end convertible provides some insights into what a country's auto industry says about its role in the world.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:11 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835985/indian-auto-maker-balances-luxury-with-global-sustainability?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>
      <guid>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835985/indian-auto-maker-balances-luxury-with-global-sustainability?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</guid>
      <itunes:author>Sonari Glinton</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[The luxury brand Jaguar is now owned by an Indian car company, Tata. A drive through the Los Angeles hills in a super high-end convertible provides some insights into what a country's auto industry says about its role in the world.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>
      <itunes:duration>286</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>
      <enclosure url="http://public.npr.org/anon.npr-mp3/npr/atc/2016/05/20160512_atc_indian_auto_maker_balances_luxury_with_global_sustainability.mp3?sc=16&orgId=1&forsearch=0&topicId=1006&d=286&p=2&story=477835985&t=progseg&e=477760873&seg=12&ft=ryop&f=1007" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Car Rationing Experiment Backfires In Polluted New Delhi</title>
      <description><![CDATA[New Delhi has the most polluted air of any city in the world. NPR explores whether rationing cars in the Indian city could solve the problem.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 16:27:01 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/11/477693482/car-rationing-experiment-backfires-in-polluted-new-delhi?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>
      <guid>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/11/477693482/car-rationing-experiment-backfires-in-polluted-new-delhi?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</guid>
      <itunes:author>Ari Shapiro</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[New Delhi has the most polluted air of any city in the world. NPR explores whether rationing cars in the Indian city could solve the problem.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>
      <itunes:duration>377</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>

    <item>
      <title>Wildlife Biologists Manage Bear Interactions In America's National Parks</title>
      <description><![CDATA[There are about 1,600 black bears in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and nearly 11 million annual visitors. The park's wildlife biologists have the challenging job of managing the interactions between them.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 16:27:00 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/11/477693489/wildlife-biologists-manage-bear-interactions-in-americas-national-parks?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>
      <guid>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/11/477693489/wildlife-biologists-manage-bear-interactions-in-americas-national-parks?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</guid>
      <itunes:author>Nathan Rott</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[There are about 1,600 black bears in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and nearly 11 million annual visitors. The park's wildlife biologists have the challenging job of managing the interactions between them.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>
      <itunes:duration>449</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>
      <enclosure url="http://public.npr.org/anon.npr-mp3/npr/atc/2016/05/20160511_atc_wildlife_biologists_manage_bear_interactions_in_americas_national_parks.mp3?sc=16&orgId=1&forsearch=0&topicId=1132&aggIds=469641082&d=449&p=2&story=477693489&t=progseg&e=477615912&seg=8&ft=ryop&f=1007" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Does The Placebo Effect Influence Consumer Product Purchases?</title>
      <description><![CDATA[Novices play better golf when they have expensive brand name equipment, research shows. Brand name products alleviate some performance anxiety but brands have no effect on better players.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 05:11:00 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/11/477607394/does-the-placebo-effect-influence-consumer-products?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>
      <guid>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/11/477607394/does-the-placebo-effect-influence-consumer-products?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</guid>
      <itunes:author>Shankar Vedantam</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[Novices play better golf when they have expensive brand name equipment, research shows. Brand name products alleviate some performance anxiety but brands have no effect on better players.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>
      <itunes:duration>218</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>
      <enclosure url="http://public.npr.org/anon.npr-mp3/npr/me/2016/05/20160511_me_does_the_placebo_effect_influence_consumer_products.mp3?sc=16&orgId=1&forsearch=0&topicId=1024&d=218&p=3&story=477607394&t=progseg&e=477607350&seg=4&ft=ryop&f=1007" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>NASA Spots 1,284 New Planets, Including 9 That Are 'Potentially Habitable'</title>
      <description><![CDATA[Of the more than 1,200 planets in the latest trove turned up by NASA's Kepler Space Telescope, about half seem to be rocky, like Earth.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 16:33:00 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/05/10/477517003/nasa-spots-1-284-new-planets-including-9-that-are-potentially-habitable?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>
      <guid>http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/05/10/477517003/nasa-spots-1-284-new-planets-including-9-that-are-potentially-habitable?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</guid>
      <itunes:author>Nell Greenfieldboyce</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[Of the more than 1,200 planets in the latest trove turned up by NASA's Kepler Space Telescope, about half seem to be rocky, like Earth.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>
      <itunes:duration>173</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>
      <itunes:image href="https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2016/05/10/planets_wide-2dd7e2338471c4fc0288e2316d2392e76708073b.jpg?s=1400"/>
      <enclosure url="http://public.npr.org/anon.npr-mp3/npr/atc/2016/05/20160510_atc_nasa_spies_1284_new_planets_including_9_that_might_support_life.mp3?sc=16&orgId=1&forsearch=0&topicId=1007&d=173&p=2&story=477517003&t=progseg&e=477454505&seg=6&ft=ryop&f=1007" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Army Corps Of Engineers Blocks Pacific Northwest Coal Terminal</title>
      <description><![CDATA[In a blow to the coal industry, a new terminal in the Pacific Northwest was denied approval after opposition from environmental groups and a debate between local Native American tribes.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 16:25:00 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/10/477529342/army-corps-of-engineers-blocks-pacific-northwest-coal-terminal?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>

      <itunes:author>Eric Whitney</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[In a blow to the coal industry, a new terminal in the Pacific Northwest was denied approval after opposition from environmental groups and a debate between local Native American tribes.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>

    <item>
      <title>WOOP, There It Is! 4 Steps To Achieve Your Goals</title>
      <description><![CDATA[Positive thinking feels good but it may actually stop you from achieving your goals. This week, we discuss a different approach called WOOP.]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>India Struggles To Develop Without Furthering Carbon Footprint</title>
      <description><![CDATA[How does a country bring its people into the 21st century without pumping huge amounts of carbon into the atmosphere? This challenge is more acute in India than anywhere else.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 16:28:00 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/09/477382518/india-struggles-to-develop-without-furthering-carbon-footprint?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>

      <itunes:author>Ari Shapiro</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[How does a country bring its people into the 21st century without pumping huge amounts of carbon into the atmosphere? This challenge is more acute in India than anywhere else.]]></itunes:summary>

      <itunes:duration>333</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>

    <item>
      <title>Top Medical Journals Give Women Researchers Short Shrift </title>
      <description><![CDATA[Women scientists get first-author credit on medical studies much less often than their male coauthors. That has career implications and could even be skewing the study of women's health.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 16:28:00 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/09/476627522/top-medical-journals-give-women-researchers-short-shrift?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>
      <guid>http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/09/476627522/top-medical-journals-give-women-researchers-short-shrift?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</guid>
      <itunes:author>Lauren Silverman</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[Women scientists get first-author credit on medical studies much less often than their male coauthors. That has career implications and could even be skewing the study of women's health.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>
      <itunes:duration>268</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>
      <itunes:image href="https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2016/05/09/scientists-1_wide-c4edf2bb5a47d64836a280ab57df1f9aa722e7ea.jpg?s=1400"/>
      <enclosure url="http://public.npr.org/anon.npr-mp3/npr/atc/2016/05/20160509_atc_women_arent_taking_first_place_in_top_medical_journals_.mp3?sc=16&orgId=77&forsearch=0&topicId=1128&d=268&p=2&story=476627522&t=progseg&e=477303123&seg=12&ft=ryop&f=1007" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Notorious FDA? Feds Turn To Hip-Hop To Tamp Down Teen Smoking</title>
      <description><![CDATA[For its latest anti-tobacco campaign, the Food and Drug Administration wants to harness hip-hop swagger to reach minority teens — who disproportionately suffer the consequences of smoking.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 04:26:00 -0400</pubDate>

      <itunes:author>Maanvi Singh</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[For its latest anti-tobacco campaign, the Food and Drug Administration wants to harness hip-hop swagger to reach minority teens — who disproportionately suffer the consequences of smoking.]]></itunes:summary>

    <item>
      <title>In The Midst Of A Downturn, Some In Oil Industry Are Prepping For A Bounce</title>
      <description><![CDATA[The plunging price of crude oil is good for motorists but bad for those in the industry. And nowhere is that pain more acute than in West Texas, where many are hunkered down with an eye on the future.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Sun, 08 May 2016 17:16:00 -0400</pubDate>
      <link>http://www.npr.org/2016/05/08/477257935/in-the-midst-of-a-downturn-some-in-oil-industry-are-prepping-for-a-bounce?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=science</link>

      <itunes:author>Lorne Matalon</itunes:author>
      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[The plunging price of crude oil is good for motorists but bad for those in the industry. And nowhere is that pain more acute than in West Texas, where many are hunkered down with an eye on the future.]]></itunes:summary>
      <itunes:subtitle/>
      <itunes:duration>237</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>no</itunes:explicit>

      <title>Ringling Elephants Retire To Florida For Cancer Research</title>
      <description><![CDATA[The Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus no longer uses elephants in its shows. The animals are heading for retirement in Florida. But their work isn't done yet.]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>Massive Canada Wildfires Continue To Spread</title>
      <description><![CDATA[Fires continue to rage in Alberta, Canada, threatening neighboring provinces. NPR's Melissa Block speaks with CBC reporter Evan Dyer about the continuing crisis.]]></description>
      <pubDate>Sun, 08 May 2016 07:57:39 -0400</pubDate>

      <itunes:summary><![CDATA[Fires continue to rage in Alberta, Canada, threatening neighboring provinces. NPR's Melissa Block speaks with CBC reporter Evan Dyer about the continuing crisis.]]></itunes:summary>
